data.attributionText: from The American Heritage速 Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A large deciduous tree (Tectona grandis) in the mint family, native to tropical South and Southeast Asia, having hard, heavy, durable yellowish-brown wood.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage速 Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: The wood of this tree, used especially for furniture and in shipbuilding.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage速 Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A grayish yellowish brown or grayish to moderate brown.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage速 Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: An East Indian timber-tree, Tectona grandis, or its wood.
A tree of East Indies (<spn>Tectona grandis</spn>) which furnishes an extremely strong and durable timber highly valued for shipbuilding and other purposes; also, the timber of the tree.
data.attributionText: from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.

data.text: a tree (<spn>Oldfieldia Africana</spn>) of Sierra Leone; also, its very heavy and durable wood; -- called also <altname>African oak</altname>.
data.attributionText: from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.

data.text: a large tree (<spn>Vitex littoralis</spn>) of New Zeland; also, its hard, durable timber.
data.attributionText: from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.

data.text: An extremely durable timber highly valued for shipbuilding and other purposes, yielded by Tectona grandis (and Tectona spp.).

data.text: A tree of the species in the genus Tectona
data.attributionText: from Wiktionary, Creative Commons Attribution/Share-Alike License.
